Yola sells and manufactures milk and needs a loan for the purchase of a milking cow.  Her husband helps her out working as a bricklayer in La Paz, but what they both earn is not enough.  It is for this reason the Yola would like your help.  She enjoys her good health and is very hardworking.

loans.use: to purchase a milking cow.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children with 2 of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Mary has been working hard to manage her business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy African materials, and will help Mary to generate greater profits and improve business. Mary hopes that in the future she will be able to improve her business. 

Mary is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mary who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy African materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase tools such as pressing machines, and drills, as well as acquiring a small shop to start his business.

loans.name: Yamilka

texts.es:
Yamilka , es soltera tiene una hija de 10 meses de edad, vive en casa de sus padres, la misma se encuentra ubicada en la ciudad de El Alto.
Ella estudio hasta el nivel secundario. Se dedida a la confeccion de vestidos de niña para acontecimientos (Bautizo) y otros trabajos de confeccion en general. 
El crédito lo requiere para la compra  de tela. Yamilka es la unica fuente de ingresos en su hogar
texts.en:
Yamilka is single and has a 10-month-old daughter. She lives in her parents' home, located in the city of El Alto.

She has a high school education. She makes children's dresses for events (baptisms), and other general sewing work.

She needs the loan in order to buy fabric. Yamilka is the sole source of income for her household.

loans.use: To buy fabric.

loans.name: Abdalla

texts.en:
Abdalla is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase many different kinds of foods to be able to meet his customers' demands

loans.name: Mariela

texts.es: Mariela vive en concubinato pero no tiene hijos, ella vive con sus padres en Chijipina Grande en una casa de adobe que es propia, la casa tiene luz y agua  Mariela es agricultora y necesita un credito para comprar una vaca lechera, aunque sus padres la apoyan, el dinero no alcanza por eso ella quiere su ayuda, Mariela goza de buena salud y su evaluacion de credito es buena
texts.en: Mariela lives with her companion but has no children. She resides with her parents in Chijipina Grande in an adobe house she owns. The house has lights and water. Mariela is a farmer and needs a loan to purchase a milk cow. Although her parents help her, the money is insufficient for this. Mariela wants your help. She enjoys good health and her credit evaluation is good.

loans.use: buy a milk cow.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es: Carmen esta casada desde hace doce años y tiene 4 hijos Vive en la comunidad de Umapusa en una casa de adobe  que es propia, la casa tiene luz y agua  Carmen se dedica a la produccion y venta de leche  y quiere un prestamo para comprar una vaca lechera que le ayude a incrementar su produccion, si bien el esposo trabaja como promotor de sanidad de ganado vacuno, lo que gana no alcanza y Carmen necesita rapidamente el dinero
texts.en:
Carmen has been married for 12 years and has four children. She lives in the community of Umapusa in an adobe home that she owns. The home has electricity and water. Carmen produces and sells milk, and wants a loan in order to buy a dairy cow, which will help her increase her production.  

Her husband works as a cattle health promoter, but what he earns is insufficient and Carmen needs the money in the short term.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Maria Marta

texts.es: Doña Maria de 47 años de edad posee un taller de costura desde hace varios años y posee mucha clientela por la calidad con que elabora lasa prendas de vestir, vive en casa propia con compañero de vida y sus cuatro hijos, ella esta solicitando un creidito para comprar botones, telas, agujas,  hilos, etc. y continuar con su trabajo
texts.en: Maria is 47 years old. She has had a sewing shop for several years and has a lot of customers because of the quality of the clothing she makes. She lives in her own house with her life's companion and their four children. She is asking for a loan to buy buttons, fabrics, needles, threads, etc. and to continue with her work.

loans.use: to buy buttons, fabrics, needles, threads, etc.

loans.name: Bashiran

texts.en: Bashiran is 55, living in the rural area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of seven children. Her son owns a fuel and oil sales agency in the market. He purchases oil from different petrol stations at a wholesale rate and sells to the customers on a daily basis at a profitable price. He has built up very good relations with his customers and that is the reason demand for oil from his agency has increased. To cope with the demand he wants to buy more oil for resale. Moreover he manages his household necessities through this oil sales business so he decided to increase his current business on a daily basis. Therefore, Bashiran, his mother, requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan to support her son's business. She is thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase her son's fuel and oil sales business.

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Andrew is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende, in the Fortportal region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, three of them currently in school. For the past two years, Andrew has been working hard to manage his retail shop, where he sells eggs, bread, water, sodas, soap, sugar, rice, posho, and groundnuts.

To help expand his business, Andrew has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more eggs, bread, water, sodas, soap, sugar, rice, posho, and groundnuts. It will help Andrew to generate greater profits and pay school fees. Andrew hopes that in the future, he will be able to build a guest house.

Andrew is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Andrew, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell at his store, including rice, posho, and groundnuts

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: El joven a quien se le ha pixeleado la cara por tener 27 años de edad y vivir en zona de lato riesgo, se dedica a la agricultura desde hace algunos años, posee mucha clientela por los buenos precios,  el joven vive en casa propia con sus padres y su hermano, el esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, controles e plagas, etc. y mejorar el terreno para continuar con sus siembras ya que esa es su única fuente de trabajo
texts.en: This young man whose face is pixelated because he is 27 years old and lives in a high risk area. He has worked in farming for several years. He has a lot of customers because of his good prices. He lives in his own house with his parents and his brother. He is asking for a loan to buy seeds, fertilizer, pest control, etc. and to improve the soil so he can continue with his crops since this is his only source of income.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer, pest control, etc., and to improve the soil.

loans.name: Petero

texts.en:
Petero is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo, in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, four of them currently in school. For the past seven years, Petero has been working hard to manage his retail shop, where he sells beer, sodas, salt, soap, and sugar.

To help expand his business, Petero has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beer, sodas, salt, soap, and sugar. This will help Petero to generate greater profits and increase business profits. Petero hopes that in the future, he will be able to enhance the business.

Petero is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Peter who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell at his store, including salt, soap, and sugar

loans.name: Paula Graciela

texts.es: Paula de 38 años de edad vive con su grupo familiar, ella posee una pequeña tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia desde hace varios años, esta solicitando un credito para la compra de sopas, huevos, café, refrescos, golosinas, etc. y asi poder continuar con sus ventas que le generan buenas ganancias.
texts.en: Paula is 38 years old and lives with her family group. She has operated a small store in her place of residence for various years. Paula is requesting a loan to purchase soups, eggs, coffee, soft drinks, sweets, etc., and thus, to be able to continue with the sales that have generated good earnings for her.

loans.use: buy soups, eggs, coffee, soft drinks, sweets, etc. for her store.

loans.name: Oscar Ovidio

texts.es: Oscar de 34 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposa y su hijo, el se dedica desde hace varios años al cultivo de berenjenas y frijol, comercializa sus productos en los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su casa, Oscar esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, herbicidas, etc. para poder continuar con sus siembras.
texts.en: Oscar is 34 years old and lives in a house he owns with his wife and son. For a few years he has cultivated eggplants and beans and sold them at various markets around his house. Oscar is asking for a loan to buy fertilisers, manure, pest control, herbicide, etc so he can continue to grow his crops.

loans.use: buy fertilisers, manure, pest control, herbicide, etc so he can continue to grow his crops.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 40 years old and lives in the town of Masaka in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is married and has four children with none of them currently in school. In the past, Jane has been working hard to manage her clothing sales business, which sells clothes.

To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes, and will help Jane to generate greater profits and increase the family income. Jane hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business.

Jane is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jane who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy more clothes

loans.name: Abdalla

texts.en:
Abdalla is a married woman with six children, She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past six years, she has operated a food kiosk business, selling food stuff such as maize flour, rice, and cooking fat to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned the high cost of seasonality as her major challenge. Abdalla dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Milly is 33 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende, in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, who are both currently in school. For the past eight years, Milly has been working hard to manage her salon, where she provides services in hair dressing.

To help expand her business, Milly has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy items like braids and treatment chemicals. This will help Milly to generate greater profits and construct a house. Milly hopes that in the future, she will be able to open up a beauty parlour.

Milly is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Milly, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy items to use at her salon, like braids and treatment chemicals

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 48 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo, in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. He is married and has six children, four of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Joseph has been working hard to manage his retail shop, where he sells beers, sodas, salt, soap, and sugar.

To help expand his business, Joseph has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beers, sodas, salt, soap, and sugar. This will help Joseph to generate greater profits. Joseph hopes that in the future, he will be able to enhance the business.

Joseph is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joseph, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell at his store, including salt, soap, and sugar

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es: Marcela esta casada y vive en Umapusa ella vive en una casa de adobe que es propia Marcela se dedica a la elaboracion de queso, su producto es vendido en otras comunidades  y necesita un prestamo para comprar una vaca lechera que le sirva para incrementar su produccion, su esposo es albañil pero tambien tiene sus propios gastos por eso Marcela necesita su ayuda
texts.en:
Marcela is married and lives in Umapusa. She lives in an adobe house that she owns. Marcela earns a living making cheese, and her product is sold in other communities. She is requesting a loan to buy a dairy cow that will help her to increase her production.

Her husband is a brick mason but he also has his own expenses. For this reason Marcela needs the lenders help.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Dalaus

texts.en:
Dalaus is 35 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo in the Kampala region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children, who are all currently in school. For the past 7 years, Dalaus has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sugar, rice, beans, and posho. 

To help expand his business, Dalaus has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more stock of rice, sugar, beans, and posho. This will also help him to generate greater profits and increase on the volume of the stock. Dalaus hopes that in the future he will be able to have increased stock. 

Dalaus is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Dalaus who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: purchase more stock of rice, sugar, beans and posho

loans.name: Ireene

texts.en:
Ireene is 36 years old and lives in the town of Gaba in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has four children with two of them currently in school. For the past 14 years, Ireene has been working hard to manage her retail business, which sells polythene bags.

To help expand her business, Ireene has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more brands of polythene, and will help Ireene to generate greater profits and get other household items. Ireene hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another branch in other landing sites.

Ireene is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Ireene who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: purchase more brands of polythene

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 33 years old and married, and she and her spouse have been blessed with two children. She has a clothes selling business, which she has been running for 3 years now. Her spouse also provides additional income to support the family.

She will be using this loan to replenish her stock of clothes and handbags to sell. She will use the anticipated profits to expand her business.

This is Catherine's first loan term with Visionfund Kenya, and in the future she hopes to open a boutique shop and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy clothes and handbags to sell.

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah is 38 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children who are all currently in school. For the past 8 years, Robinah has been working hard to manage her clothing shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Robinah has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy skirts, t-shirts, and trousers, which will help Robinah generate greater profits. Robinah hopes that in the future she will be able to get a plot of land. 

Robinah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Robinah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy skirts, t-shirts, and trousers.

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en: Sareth is a 32-year-old garment-factory worker and she is single. She has worked as a garment-factory worker since 2010. She lives with her old father and a brother in the Kampong Speu Province of Cambodia. Being a garment-factory worker, Sareth can earn approximately $5 a day. Now she would like to request a loan to buy clothes to resell in her free time from work. This loan will help her earn more income to support the family. In the future, she is going to renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy clothes to resell.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is 48 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 7 years, Hassan has been working hard to manage his spare parts business, which sells spare parts. 

To help expand his business, Hassan has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more spare parts, and will help Hassan to generate greater profits and generate more sales. Hassan hopes that in the future he will be able to increase his income. 

Hassan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hassan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to increase his spare parts inventory.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 34 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo, in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, who are all currently in school. For the past seven years, Patrick has been working hard to manage his welding shop, where he welds items like gates, doors, and windows.

To help expand his business, Patrick has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more materials for welding, and will help Patrick to generate greater profits and improve on the size of the business. Patrick hopes that in the future, he will be able to purchase more stock.

Patrick is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Patrick, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more materials for welding items like gates, doors, and windows

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is 39 years old and lives in the town of Nakaloke, in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of them currently in school. For the past six years, Julius has been working hard to manage his retail shop, where he sells sugar, soap, water, cooking oil, soda, beer, and tea leaves.

To help expand his business, Julius has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more sugar, soap, water, cooking oil, soda, beer, and tea leaves. This will help Julius to generate greater profits and expand the business. Julius hopes that in the future, he will be able to own a big shop.

Julius is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Julius, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell at his store, including soap, cooking oil, soda, beer, and tea leaves

loans.name: Luis

texts.es: Luis es soltero, no tiene hijos y vive con sus padres en La Paz en una casa de ladrillo y cemento que le pertenece a su familia Luis desea terminar sus estudios superiores, solo le falta la tesis de grado y solicita un credito para cubrir esta inversion como tramites, compra de material, pago de matricula Luis necesita su ayuda, goza de buena salud y es una persona responsable
texts.en:
Luis is single, has no children, and lives with his parents in La Paz. They live in a brick and cement house that belongs to his family. Luis wants to finish his graduate studies. The only item he has left to finish is his graduate thesis. He is requesting a loan to cover the costs such as, processing fees, purchase of materials, and the registration fee. 

Luis needs the lenders' help. He is in great health, and is a responsible person.

loans.use: to pay for processing fees, purchase of materials, registration fee and other costs for his graduate thesis.

loans.name: Mariya

texts.ru:
Мария — из Трускавца. Ей 48 лет, она замужем, есть 2 детей. Мария торгует там детской одеждой. Мария живет в однокомнатной квартире, давно хочет расширить жилплощадь. С разрешения местного БТИ она смогла сделать комнату в подвале и теперь хочет сделать вход с улицы, а также сделать ванную комнату. 
Средства в размере 40 000 гривен нужны Марии на ремонт, реконструкцию и переоборудование жилого помещения. Сделанные изменения помогут Марии в конце концов расширить жилплощадь и воплотить свою давнюю мечту в реальность.
texts.en: Maria is from Truskavyets. She is 48, married, and has two children. She sells children’s clothing. She lives in a studio apartment and has wanted to expand her living space for a long time. She received permission from the local BTI to make a room in the basement and would now like to add a street entrance and a bathroom. Maria needs 40,000 hryvnia to repair, construct, and equip the space. The changes will help her expand her living area and finally make her dream a reality.

loans.use: to remodel an addition to her apartment

loans.name: Muhammed

texts.en:
Muhammed is 25 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala region of Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past five years, Muhammed has been working hard to manage his electronics shop, which sells electronics.

To help expand his business, Muhammed has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy a television set, extension cable, bulbs and dvds, and will help Muhammed to generate greater profits and earn more. Muhammed hopes that in the future he will be able to buy land for farming.

Muhammed is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Muhammed who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy a television set, extension cable, bulbs and dvds

loans.name: Pascal

texts.en:
Pascal is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortportal region of Uganda. He is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Pascal has been working hard to manage his coffee business.

To help expand his business, Pascal has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sacks of coffee, and will help Pascal to generate greater profits and improve standards of living. Pascal hopes that in the future he will be able to improve stock. 

Pascal is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Pascal who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of coffee.

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank is 45 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo, in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, three of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Frank has been working hard to manage his produce business, where he sells foods like beans, posho, peas, and soya.

To help expand his business, Frank has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beans, posho, peas, and soya. This will help Frank to generate greater profits and expand the business. Frank hopes that in the future, he will be able to acquire more profits.

Frank is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Frank, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell, including beans, posho, and peas

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 34 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past six years, Ruth has been working hard to manage her salon, which deals in hair dressing. 

To help expand her business, Ruth has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase braids, body lotions, hair spray, and hair chemicals, and will help Ruth to generate greater profits and business expansion. Ruth hopes that in the future she will be able to earn still more profits. 

Ruth is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Ruth who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase braids, body lotions, hair spray, and hair chemicals

loans.name: Emiriano

texts.en:
Emiriano is 45 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past five years, Emiriano has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells salt, cooking oil, millet flour, sugar, etc. 

To help expand his business, Emiriano has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy items like millet flour, sugar, and salt and will help Emiriano to generate greater profits and business expansion. Emiriano hopes that in the future he will be able to achieve his targeted goal. 

Emiriano is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Emiriano who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy items like millet flour, sugar, and salt

loans.name: Irma Noemy

texts.es: Irma de 50 años de edad es una mujer muy trabajadora, posee un negocio de venta de comida esa ubicada en una zona muy céntrica por eso posee mucha clientela, vive en casa propia con su esposo y su hijos, ella esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de materia prima como: pollos, carnes, verduras, frutas, arroz, etc. para seguir con su negocio que le genera buenas ganancias.
texts.en: Irma is 50 years old. She is a very hardworking woman. She has a business selling food. It is located in a very central area and that is why she has a lot of customers. She lives in her own house with her husband and children. She is asking for a loan to buy raw materials such as chicken, meats, vegetables, fruit, rice, etc. to continue with her business that generates good profits for her.

loans.use: to buy chickens, meats, vegetables, fruits, rice, etc.

loans.name: Asmahan

texts.en:
Asmahan is a 36-year-old, married woman from Rafah city. She is a mother for two sons and four daughters. Her husband works as an employee in the public sector. He earns a low income, which is not enough to cover all the family's needs. Asmahan and her husband would like to improve their living conditions. They decided to buy a new rickshaw, so Asmahan's husband will be able to work with it.

Asmahan took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help her to buy a new rickshaw for her husband to work with. By taking this loan, they will increase the family income and improve their living conditions. Asmahan appears in the photo

loans.use: to buy a new rickshaw for her husband to work with

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 37 years old and lives in the town of Lukaya in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past four years, Rehema has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, maize flour, beans, groundnuts, etc. 

To help expand her business, Rehema has requested a loan of 3,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more  sugar, maize flour, beans, and groundnuts, and will help Rehema to generate greater profits and stock up the shop. Rehema hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her stock. 

Rehema is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rehema who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more  sugar, maize flour, beans, and groundnuts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a water purification machine for the family house.

loans.name: Steven

texts.en:
Steven is 40 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children, 3 of whom are currently in school. For the past 8 years, Steven has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sodas, juice, sugar, and other pantry goods. 

To help expand his business, Steven has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more soda, water, blue band, juice, sugar, and cooking oil, which will help Steven increase his spending money and expand the business. Steven hopes that in the future he will be able to earn more profits. 

Steven is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Steven who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: purchase more soda, water, blue band, juice, sugar, and cooking oil for his store.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water.

Mejumaa has operated a beauty salon business for the past three years, operating at the market where her customers are passersby and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to add stock of shampoo, conditioner and hair braids to her beauty salon business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to add stock of shampoo, conditioner and hair braids (extensions) to her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Mwanarusi

texts.en:
Mwanarusi is a married woman living together with her husband and eight children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a paraffin-selling business. She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding her business to become a wholesale supplier of paraffin in the village. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase jerrycans of paraffin for resale. She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase jerrycans of paraffin for resale

loans.name: Teófilo

texts.es:
Teófilo de 63 años de edad, estudió hasta quinto grado, no pudo continuar por motivo económicos, ahora está casado y su esposa trabaja en una clínica, tiene un hijo que estudia 4to grado en la escuela, y son las únicas personas que dependen de Teófilo.


Él se dedica a trabajar como albañil desde hace 15 años, lo aprendió cuando era auxiliar luego vio que podía desempeñar el trabajo poniendo en práctica su experiencia. Anteriormente era jornalero, sembraba granos básicos como maíz y frijol. Él trabaja de 6:00 AM  a 12:30 MD.



Teófilo necesita el crédito para pagar una deuda que tiene con un amigo, y con el resto del crédito comprará insumos agrícolas para los cultivos. 

Su sueño es construir una vivienda en un lote que posee.
texts.en:
Teófilo, 63 years old, attended school until the fifth grade. He was unable to continue beyond that due to financial reasons. Now he is married and his wife works in a clinic. He has a son who is in the fourth grade and they are the only people who are dependent on him.

Teófilo has been a construction worker for 15 years. He learned the trade when he was an assistant and then saw that he could perform the tasks by putting his experience into practice. Formerly he was a day laborer, planting basic grains such as corn and beans. He works from 6 a.m. until 12:30 p.m.

Teófilo needs the loan to repay a debt he owes a friend and with the remainder of the loan he will purchase farming supplies for his crops.

His dream is to build a house on a lot that he owns.

loans.use: to repay a debt he owes a friend and with the remainder of the loan he will buy farming supplies for his crops.

loans.name: José Guadalupe

texts.es:
José de 40 años de edad, es agricultor por problemas económicos en que vivían sus padres él no estudio y mejor se dedico ayudar a su padre en el trabajo, paraaportar dinero para la alimentación de él y de sus padres, luego decidió acompañarse y ahora es padre de 4 hijos de 16, 14, 12 y 5 años de edad; de los cuales dos de ellos se encuentran estudiando y los otros dos le ayudan a trabajar en la agricultura, José vive con sus 4 hijos y su compañera de vida son los que depende de él.

Su compañera de vida se dedica a la crianza de pollos y de cerdos mientras que José se dedica a la siembra de maíz (agricultura) desde hace mas de 25 años, trabajo que lo aprendió de su padre quien toda su vida se ha dedicado a la agricultura, también trabaja como seguridad en un cañal donde también obtiene un ingreso mas para ayudar a su familia en la alimentación, para llegar a su trabajo José viaja en bicicleta 2 kilómetros trabajando en el horario de 7:00 am a 2:00 pm.

El crédito que esta solicitando, es para comprar 4 novillas para la crianza y así mejorara su negocio también lo utilizara para aumentar un poco la crianza de cerdos y pollos donde espera tener un mejor ingreso para darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
 
El sueño de José es aumentar el negocio de la crianza de animales, darle estudio a sus hijos para que sean profesionales y ahorrar mucho para construir una casita, para darle una mejor seguridad a sus hijos ya que la que tiene es una de adobe.
texts.en:
José, 40, is a farmer. Due to his parents' financial difficulties, he didn't go to school and instead helped his father with work to earn money for food. He later decided to get into a relationship and now he is a father of four children ages 16, 14, 12, and 5. Two of his children are in school and the other two help work in farming. José lives with his four children and his life partner, all of whom depend on him.

For the past 25 years, his life partner has worked by raising chickens and pigs while José has planted corn. He learned how to do this from his father, who was a farmer all his life. He also works in security at a canal, which also provides an income to help his family with food. To get to work, José rides a bike two kilometers and works from 7:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.

He is requesting this loan to buy four heifers to raise and improve his business. He will also use it raise more pigs and chickens, which he hopes will bring a better income so his family has a better quality of life.

José's dream is to increase his animal raising business, allow his children to go to school so they can be professionals, and save to build a small house in order to provide security to his children, since their current house is made of adobe.

loans.use: to buy four heifers to raise more chickens and pigs.

loans.name: Bopha

texts.en:
Bopha is 32 years old, a garment-factory worker and a married woman with two children, both of whom are in school. She is from the Takeo Province of Cambodia. 

Previously, Bopha and her husband were farmers. Bopha has been working in the city since 2013, and her husband works for a motorcycle company. 

Working in a city, both of them can earn approximately $8 daily. Now Bopha would like to buy a motorcycle to transport vegetables to sell in her free time after work. This loan will help her finance the motorcycle and ultimately earn more income for the family. 

In the future, she wants to build a new house because her present one is old. She also wants to be able to finance her children studying English in the city.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle to transport vegetables.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is 34 years old and lives in the town of Nakaloke in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 15 years, Benard has been working hard to manage his grocery shop. 

To help expand his business, Benard has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy tomatoes, baking flour, sugar, soap, water, cooking oil, soda, beer, and tea leaves, and will help Benard generate greater profits and expand the business. Benard hopes that in the future he will be able to own a fully-stocked shop. 

Benard is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Benard who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, baking flour, sugar, soap, water, cooking oil, soda, beer, and tea leaves.

loans.name: Señor De Los Milagros Group

texts.es:
Liliana, tiene 51 años de edad, es casada, tiene 3 hijos. Ella forma parte del grupo "Señor de los Milagros", los siete integrantes del grupo eligieron ese nombre ya que todos son creyentes de la imagen del "Señor de Los Milagros".
Liliana se dedica desde hace muchos años a la venta de productos de belleza, y actualmente ha incursionado en la elaboración de carteras, en éste negocio recibe el apoyo de su esposo y uno de sus hijos. Es una actividad que le agrada y espera lograr crecer en éste negocio ya que recién lo ha empezado.
El préstamo recibido lo invertirá en la compra de materiales para la fabricación de las carteras, materiales como retazos de cuero, cierres y otros accesorios
texts.en:
Liliana is 51 years old, is married, and has 3 children.  She is a part of the group "Señor de Los Milagros".  The seven members of the group chose this name since they are all believers in the image of "Señor de Los Milagros".

Liliana has worked for many years in the sale of beauty products, and she currently has taken on the making of handbags.  She receives support from her husband and one of her children for this business. This a work that she likes, and she hopes to grow in this business since she has started it only recently.

The loan she receives she will invest in the purchase of materials to make handbags, such as leather remnants, zippers, and other accessories.

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of materials to make handbags.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has two children who are both currently in school. For the past three years, Godfrey has been working hard to manage his stationery shop, which sells office supplies, etc. 

To help expand his business, Godfrey has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy books, reams of paper, files, glue for paper, pens, and pencils, and will help Godfrey to generate greater profits and expand the shop. Godfrey hopes that in the future he will be able to supply in larger quantities. 

Godfrey is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Godfrey who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy books, reams of paper, files, glue, pens, and pencils

loans.name: Ma Felix

texts.es:
El esfuerzo y dedicación para sacar adelante a su familia son aspectos que identifican a Doña Félix quien tiene 56 años de edad y es madre de 13 hijos. A pesar de su edad, sabe que debe trabajar con todo su empeño pues aún apoya a tres de sus hijos que viven con ella y con los estudios de dos de ellos que están a punto de terminar una carrera profesional. 

Doña Félix platica que desde que decidió formar una familia inició a trabajar como empleada doméstica para ayudar con los gastos de su hogar y la educación de sus hijos. Con los pocos ahorros de su empleo, comenzó a cultivar habas, tomates, nopales, frijoles, calabazas, etc para venderlos de casa en casa, actividad que aún conserva. sin embargo, explica que en muchas ocasiones, sus clientes no tenían dinero y comenzó a recibir despensa o ropa para sus hijos como forma de pago. Fue así como inició su tienda de abarrotes y siguió invirtiendo para tener más mercancía. Las ganancias le permitieron a Félix construir su casa y apoyar a sus hijos con sus estudios.

Debido a que se acerca la temporada de lluvias, como cada año, Félix venderá productos de limpieza y de plástico como por ejemplo, hule que las personas utilizan para proteger de la lluvia algunos espacios de sus casas. Es por eso que necesita invertir en este tipo de mercancía. Los artículos los vende en plazas, ferias, tianguis, caminando en la calle etc.

Félix se muestra muy contenta y agradecida con KIVA y VisionFund México porque le ayudará nuevamente a través del crédito a continuar con esta actividad de temporada. Por si fuera poco, ella no deja de lado las otras actividades mencionadas, ni la cría de algunos animales que también le genera un ingreso extra.

*La foto fue tomada en la tienda de abarrotes de Félix*
texts.en:
Hard work and dedication to making a living for her family are qualities that define Félix, who is 56 years old and mother to 13 children. Despite her age, she knows that she must continue putting all her dedication into her work because she still has to support the three children who live with her and help cover school expenses for the two who are close to completing professional training courses.

Félix explained that since she decided to form a family, she began working as a maid to help with household expenses and her children’s education. With the small savings from her work, she began to grow broad beans, tomatoes, prickly pear, beans, pumpkin, etc. to sell door to door. She continues this activity, but further explains that in many cases her clients didn’t have money to pay her, and she began receiving foodstuffs or clothes for her children as a form of payment. This is how her general store began, and she continues to invest in new merchandise. Her earnings have allowed Félix to build her house and help her children with their schooling. 

Because the rainy season is approaching, Félix will, like every year, sell cleaning products and plastic goods like oilcloth that people use to protect various parts of their homes from the rain. This is why she needs to invest in this type of merchandise, which will be sold in town squares, fairs, open-air markets, walking in the streets, etc. 

Félix expresses how happy and thankful she is for KIVA and VisionFund Mexico because they will again help her to ensure this seasonal activity through a loan. And as if that weren’t enough, she will not put on hold any of the other activities already mentioned, nor raising some animals, which also generates some extra income. 

*The photo was taken in Félix’s general store.*

loans.use: to buy plastic tablecloths and other plastic items such as buckets, bowls, brooms, etc.

location.town: Ejido de San Pedro El Alto, San Felipe del Progres

loans.name: Elina

texts.en: Elina is married and has three children. She has been helping her husband in their farm, to make a living. She raises pigs for sale, while her husband grows and harvests coconuts and bananas, selling them in town. With these activities, she has provided for the needs of her family and repaid successfully her previous loan, which she used for the repair of her livestock shelter. With the profits of her farming activities, she was able to put up a retail store business, and it is doing well. To add to her inventory of goods, she took a new loan from GDMPC. She is using the loan to purchase additional grocery goods for her retail store. Elina wants to see her children's success, in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery goods for her retail store.

loans.name: Cosmas

texts.en:
Cosmas has a carpentry business in Tala town. He has been running it for 24 years now. He is 49 years old, married, and together with his spouse, has been blessed with three children. 

Cosmas will be using this loan to buy more stock of timber, wood, paint, nails and fabric materials for use in his carpentry business. He will use the anticipated profits to educate his children. This is his first loan from VisionFund Kenya, and in future, he hopes to grow his business, make more profit, and be able to provide for the needs of his family.

loans.use: To buy carpentry materials.

loans.name: Janalyn

texts.en:
Janalyn is  married,  living in Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines with her family. Janalyn operates a transportation service to earn a living, and she's been operating the business for many years. With her generated revenue, she was able to put up a retail store in their village. She repaid successfully her previous loan used for buying motor spare parts. 

Now she plans to add more inventory goods to her store to offer more to her customers. She took a new loan from GDMPC micro credit to purchase additional grocery goods for her retail store.

In the future, Janalyn wants to improve her business as well as improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery goods for her retail store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more sewing materials, such as fabric, threads, zippers, and buttons.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a selection of products such as creams, deodorants, lotions, and rinses wholesale so she can stock her small business with quality products.

loans.name: Reacheal

texts.en:
Reacheal is 28 years old and lives in the town of Wobulenzi, in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, who are both currently in school. For the past five years, Reacheal has been working hard to manage her beauty salon, where she provides services like hair dressing.

To help expand her business, Reacheal has requested a loan of 3,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more hair relaxers and braids for the salon. This will help Reacheal to generate greater profits and take good care of her family's basic needs. Reacheal hopes that in the future, she will be able to open up a beauty training school.

Reacheal is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Reacheal, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more hair relaxers and braids for the salon

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 35 years old and married. Together with her spouse, she has been blessed with two children. She sells retail goods and has been in this business for four years, now.

She will be using this loan to buy more stock of retail goods, such as detergents, polythene bags, and tissue paper. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her children. This is her second loan term with VisionFund Kenya, and in future she hopes to be successful and to own a house.

loans.use: to purchase more retail goods to sell

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en: Jerry is a 25-year-old father of one. He resides in Solinog, Calamba, with his family. He has been offering transportation services for over four years, to make a living. With his income, he was able to repay his previous loan, which he used for buying motor accessories. He is now taking a new loan from GDMPC, for additional capital with which to buy a motor side car. He hopes to prosper in his business and to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to buy a motor side car.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is seventy-one years old, married, and living with his wife. He has ten children who have all completed school. He has benefited from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa training on enterprise development and financial management. This has enabled him to manage his enterprise more effectively.

Simon does mixed farming which includes vegetable farming and sheep rearing. He is borrowing a loan to buy more sheep.This will enable him to supply more sheep to the local slaughterhouse. He hopes for improved income to meet the cost of educating some of his grandchildren.

He is grateful to Kiva and the lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy more sheep.

loans.name: Lari Pioneer Vegetable Processors (C.b.o) Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Teresiah, a member of Lari Pioneer Vegetable Processors (CBO) group which joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013. She is thirty-one years old, married, and blessed with two children who are in school.

She is grateful to  Hand in Hand Eastern Africa for the  training on business development that has positively impacted her life. She has been able to open a salon and a cosmetics shop where she sells beauty products such as lotions, perfumes and skin care creams. She is borrowing a loan to expand her business by buying more cosmetics stock since the demand for beauty products in the area is very high. 

Teresiah believes that her business will give her better returns and she will be in a position to pay her children's school fees and provide their basic needs such as clothing and food.

Teresiah is very grateful to Kiva and Kiva lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cosmetics such as lotion, skin care creams, and perfumes.

loans.name: Hajarah

texts.en:
Hajarah is 25 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala east region of Uganda. For the past seven years, Hajarah has been working hard to manage her boutique, from where she sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Hajarah has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for sale, and will help Hajarah to generate greater profits and take good care of her parents' basic needs. Hajarah hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a big shopping mall. 

Hajarah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hajarah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Noemi De Jesus

texts.es: Noemí de 45 años de edad habita en vivienda propia junto a su esposo y sus 3 hijos 2 muchachas mayores de edad y un varón de 14 años de edad. Ella es una mujer que siempre se ha caracterizado por su dedicación y esmero para sacar adelante a su familia y es ese ánimo de salir adelante el que la ha llevado a elaborar carteras de cuero desde hace mucho tiempo, lo que le permite dar un aporte económico a su hogar. Noemí desea realizar la instalación de energía eléctrica, dos puertas y dos ventanas en su vivienda por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: dos puertas, dos ventanas, alambre y caja térmica para instalar dos puertas, dos ventanas y energía eléctrica en su vivienda.
texts.en: Noemí is 45 years old. She lives in her own home with her husband and their 3 children, 2 grown daughters and a 14 year old son. She is a woman who is always characterized by her dedication and hard work to get her family ahead and that spirit of getting ahead is what has brought her to making leather purses for a long time. This allows her to contribute to the household economy. Noemí wants to install electricity, two doors and two windows and that is why she is asking FUSAI for a loan to invest in two doors, two windows, wire, and a thermal box to install the two doors, two windows, and electricity in her house.

loans.use: to invest in two doors, two windows, wire and a thermal box to install two doors, two windows and electricity in her home.

loans.name: Gustavo Adolfo

texts.es: Gustavo de 42 años de edad vive con su esposa en casa propia, el se dedica a la crianza de cerdos desde hace 5 años, comercializa sus productos en los diferentes mercados,  Gustavo esta solicitando un préstamo a INTEGRAL para la compra de concentrado y mas cerdos para seguir con la crianza y poder generar mejores ganancias.
texts.en:
Gustavo is 42 years old and lives with his wife in their own home. For the past five years, he has made a living by raising pigs. He sells his products in various markets.

Gustavo is requesting a loan from INTEGRAL to purchase animal feed and more pigs so that he can continue to raise pigs and earn more income.

loans.use: to purchase animal feed and more pigs.

loans.name: Abeza Group

texts.en:
Pelagie is a group leader; aged 24. She is married with 1 child who is 3-years-old. The group is called ABEZA means “The Great” in English. They sell different products and they wish to expand their business for changing their future for the better. 

Pelagie has a shop and has been running her business for 6 years. With the loan, she would like to buy more rice, sugar, biscuits and juice to sell. The profits from the business will be used to expand her business and renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more rice, sugar, biscuits and juice to sell.

loans.name: Pailorence

texts.en:
Pailorence is a married woman with two children, both of whom still attend school and are still under her care. They live at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for the children.

Pailorence operates a clothes-selling business. She sells at the market to her town dwellers and her neighbours. She cites her major challenge to be seasonality. Pailorence dreams of establishing a boutique in the future.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase two bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase two bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a cashew-nuts selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality, in her business.

Mwanamisi is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase sacks of cashew-nuts to resell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew-nuts to resell

loans.name: Mbaji

texts.en:
Mbaji is a married woman and lives with her husband and six children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past year, Mbaji has operated a business selling charcoal. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high costs of transportation. She dreams of expanding her business to being a wholesale supplier of firewood in the village. 

With the loan of KES 50,000 she wants to purchase bundles of charcoal for resale. She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is married and has three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past twenty years, she has operated a business selling cashew-nuts, selling at the market to her neighbours and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

Mwanamisi is requesting a loan to purchase four sacks of cashew-nuts. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase four sacks of cashew-nuts to re-sell.

loans.name: Rugongo Self Help Group

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Esther works hard to support her family. She practices both poultry and dairy farming. Esther is taking a loan to purchase animal feed and mineral supplements, and to rent an extra plot of land for growing fodder. She hopes this will improve her productivity, resulting in more income. This will go a long way toward supporting her family, by ensuring food security in her household.

Esther is happy for Kiva and the lenders, for the financial support. She is the person raising her hand, in the photo.

loans.use: to purchase animal feed and mineral supplements, and to rent an extra plot of land for growing fodder

loans.name: Carlos Enrique

texts.es:
El señor Carlos es un mecánico de motos y carros muy experimentado. 

Ha adquirido muchas habilidades a través de pequeños estudios en diferentes academias y otra parte la ha aprendido empíricamente.

Adicional a su labor como mecánico también tiene un pequeño almacén de venta de repuestos automotrices en el cual ofrece distintos tipos de repuestos en diferentes marcas.

Es un hombre muy trabajador y honrado que conoce el significado que tienen los vehículos para sus dueños y es por esto que siempre trata de ofrecer un excelente servicio, de buena calidad y de una manera eficiente.

El solicita un préstamo para surtir su almacén con gran cantidad de repuestos, de este modo podrá tener los productos disponibles para sus clientes.

Con este préstamo podrá sacar su negocio adelante y sostener a su pequeño hijo de 3 años.
texts.en:
Carlos is a very experienced mechanic who works on cars and motorcycles. He has acquired many skills by working in different studios in many academies and has also learned through experience. In addition to his work as a mechanic, he has a small auto parts store where he offers many brands of parts.

He is a very hardworking and honorable man who knows the significance of cars to their owners, so he always offers excellent, high-quality services in an efficient manner.

He requests a loan to stock his business with a large variety of parts so that he will be able to have products available for his customers. With this loan, he will be able to move his business forward and support his 3-year-old son.

loans.use: to stock his store with a great variety of parts so that he can have products available for his customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more food items for the future expansion of his business.

loans.name: Doan Cam's Group

texts.en:
Mrs Doan Thi Cam, born in 1961, is of the Kinh (Vietnamese) people. She currently lives in Mai Son district, Son La province. Her family consists of five members, her husband, her daughter, and her son-in-law, and a new grandson who has just turned one year old. 
	
	
Her main occupation is animal husbandry. With little funds, she raises three groups of pigs each year. The small amount she makes by selling pigs helps her get a little to cover the living expenses of the family. Upon learning and participation in the savings and credit program of M7-MFI in 2013, she had the opportunity to get loans in order to expand her animal husbandry.

	
At present she wants to take out a new loan. With this new loan, she will invest more in raising piglets of high economic value and develop her sow scale. She expects this change will improve the family's livestock breeding, bringing higher income, and help her family have a prosperous life, her kids have enough food to eat, and allow them to complete their education.

loans.use: to expand her animal husbandry.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 32 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala east region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past six years, Aisha has been working hard to manage her pharmacy shop, which sells drugs. 

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drugs and some lab equipment for the pharmacy, and will help Aisha to generate greater profits and improve on her family's standards of living. Aisha hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a clinic. 

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Aisha who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more drugs and some lab equipment for the pharmacy.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 37 years old and lives in the town of Maganjo in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has five children, with four of them currently in school. For the past five years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her mini-supermarket, which sells essential goods such as sugar, salt, and water. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items, such as sugar, rice, and all types of flour, for sale. This will help Sarah to generate greater profits, improve on her social life, and educate her children in better schools. Sarah hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand the business into a bigger supermarket. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sarah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more items, such as sugar, rice, and all types of flour, for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a water purification machine for the family house.

loans.name: Habsatou's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe est créé depuis mai 2010.Il est composé de membres qui habitent le même quartier et ont comme activité le commerce.

Diénaba qui se trouve à droite de la photo et levant le bras,est la responsable du groupe,elle est âgée de 41 ans,elle est mariée, et mére de 05 enfants ,elle pratique comme activité la vente de bois.

Elle achéte du bois qu'elle charge dans un camion pour le revendre à Dakar.

Ainsi avec son crédit,elle compte acheter du bois pour 400000f et supporter des frais de transport pour 200000f.

Son objectif est d'assurer la scolarité de ses enfants,leur santé et leur nourriture.
texts.en:
This group was created in May 2010. It is comprised of members who live in the same neighborhood and who work in business. 

Diénaba, pictured at right with her hand raised, is the group manager. She is 41 years old, married, and has 5 children. 

She sells wood. She buys wood that she brings in a truck to resell in Dakar.

With her loan, she would like to pay for 400,000 FCFA worth of wood and 200,000 FCFA worth of transportation fees. 

Her goal is to take care of her children's schooling, health, and food.

loans.use: to buy wood.

loans.name: Flavia

texts.en:
Flavia is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children with 2 of them currently in school. For the past 4 years, Flavia has been working hard to manage her business, which deals in produce sales.

To help expand her business, Flavia has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beans, maize, groundnuts, and will help Flavia to generate greater profits and complete her residential house. 

Flavia hopes that in the future she will be able to become a bigger supplier. 

Flavia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Flavia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy more beans, maize, groundnuts.

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is 47 years old and lives in the town of Mityana in the Fortportal region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children with none of them currently in school. For the past 8 years, Fred has been working hard to manage his cosmetics shop.

To help expand his business, Fred has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more cosmetic products, water and sugar, and will help Fred to generate greater profits and increase stock. 

Fred hopes that in the future he will be able to start up a mobile money business. 

Fred is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Fred who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: purchase more cosmetic products, water and sugar.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 33 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortportal region of Uganda. He is married and has 3 children with 2 of them currently in school. For the past 4 years, Robert has been working hard to manage his business, which is operating a drug shop. 

To help expand his business, Robert has requested a loan of 3,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more drugs, and will help Robert to generate greater profits and improve his business. Robert hopes that in the future he will be able to own a bigger drug shop. 

Robert is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Robert who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy medicine for his shop

loans.name: Isma

texts.en:
Isma is 27 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Fortportal region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Isma has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells beans, posho, peas, and soya. 

To help expand his business, Isma has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy beans, posho, peas, and soya, and will help Isma to generate greater profits and pay school fees. Isma hopes that in the future, he will be able to buy a motorcycle. 

Isma is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Isma who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy beans, posho, peas, and soya.

loans.name: Benita

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “IMASUMAC I”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco,  y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Benita; la socia continua dedicándose al  negocio de venta de golosinas, ella vende caramelos, chicles, chupetes y galletas, la socia lleva buen tiempo dedicándose  a su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar galletas entre otros.
 La socia se siente agradecida por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the "Imasumac I" communal bank. The bank is located in the Cusco district, which is in Cusco province in the department of Cusco. The member's name is Benita.

She continues to make a living by selling sweets. She sells candy, gum, lollipops, and cookies. She has been working in this business for a good amount of time and it is going well thanks to the effort that she puts forth every day. She hopes to continue working so that she can continue to support her family.

She requests a loan to purchase cookies and other things. She is grateful for the loan and promises to make her payments on time.

loans.use: to purchase cookies and other things.

loans.name: Florance

texts.en:
Florence, age 33, is a dairy farmer in the town of Tala. She has been engaged in this business for 10 years, and helps her husband in supporting the family. They have been blessed with three children.

This is Florence's fourth loan term with VisionFund Kenya, and she has repaid her previous loans successfully. She has now requested a loan in order to buy feed for her dairy cows. She will use the anticipated profits to improve the living standards of her family.

Her future hopes are to be successful in her business and be able to provide for her family's needs.

loans.use: To buy feed for her dairy cows

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman and has been blessed with eight kids who attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and school fees. 

Mwanajuma operated a fish selling business, which has been operational for over 7 years. She mentioned seasonality and transportation as a challenge in the business. Mwanajuma dreams of becoming a wholesaler of fish in the future. 

With the KSH 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of fish for resale. 

She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fish for resale

loans.name: Mzungu

texts.en:
Mzungu is a married woman with five kids, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Mzungu operates a grocery stall selling vegetables. She sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a challenge of the high cost of transportation to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a motorcycle transport business in the future. 

With the KSH 50,000 she wants to purchase green vegetables, 2 crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, 2 crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale.

loans.name: Ferdinand

texts.en:
Ferdinand is a 43-year-old father of three. He resides in Misamis Occidental with his family. He has a furniture shop that brings a better income to his family. Aside from this, he also has a motorcycle used for transportation services. He has his tenant as a hired hand for his transportation services business, and has developed employment for his neighbor. 

He has to work more in order to provide a better education to his children, his top priority. He wants to expand his business to ensure he has a better source of income for the family in the near future. He joined Gata Daku MPC and borrowed a new loan to buy additional raw materials for his furniture shop and to repair his motorcycle.

loans.use: to buy additional raw materials for his furniture shop and to repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Mealii

texts.en:
Mealii is married and has three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past five years, she has operated a business selling cashew-nuts, selling at the market to her neighbours and town-dwellers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

Mealii is requesting a loan to purchase six sacks of cashew-nuts. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase six sacks of cashew-nuts for resale

loans.name: Mueni

texts.en:
Mueni sells clothing to earn an income. She has been engaged in this business for the past three years, selling her wares from door to door to her neighbors and passers-by. Her primary business challenge is the high cost of transportation. 

Mueni and her husband have four children, all of whom attend school. They live in their own house, and it has electricity and piped water. Mueni's greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting a loan in the amount of Kes 20,000 in order to purchase bales of clothing to offer for sale. 

In the future, she dreams of establishing and expanding a boutique business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothing to offer for sale

loans.name: Remily

texts.en:
Vergie, age 54, earns an income by operating a "sari-sari" (general store) business, selling grocery items in her village. She lives in Zamboanga del Norte with her family. Her husband is a farmer, and his farming enterprise provides the main source of income. They have two children. Vergie has managed her store for three years, and her profits have enabled her to support the needs of her children, particularly in terms of sending them to school. 

She borrowed a loan from Gata Daku MPC in order to purchase such food items as rice and corn grits to offer for sale. 

Vergie is a hard-working mother who dreams of offering her family a better living in the future. She feels that her hard-working attitude and determination will bring this goal into reality.

loans.use: to purchase such food items as rice and corn grits to offer for sale

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a married mother of two children. They live together in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. For years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuations in her business. 

With her KES 30,000 loan she wants to purchase 3 bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. Amina dreams of establishing a hotel in the future.

loans.use: to purchase 3 bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar

loans.name: Mercedes Natividad

texts.es:
Mercedes de 35 años de edad, estudió hasta 5to grado, está acompañada y su pareja trabaja en una tienda, tiene dos hijos, uno de ellos estudia séptimo grado y el otro estudia sexto grado, con ella solo viven sus dos hijos y su pareja. 


Mercedes se dedica a la venta de comida en el cafetín de un instituto, ya tiene 2 años de trabajar en este negocio, ella por iniciativa propia decidió poner este negocio, primero solo vendía agua, galletas, pero luego fue surtiendo más y más el negocio. Antes solo se dedicaba a los oficios del hogar y dependía de los ingresos de su esposo. El lugar donde trabaja está a 15 minutos de su casa y viaja a pie, trabaja de 7 A.M a 4 PM.


Ella necesita el crédito para comprar los insumos agrícolas para fertilizar los cultivos de maíz y frijol que tiene su esposo, comprará sulfato y herbicidas para el control de la maleza. 

Mercedes sueña con surtir su negocio para que le genere más ganancias y con ello ayudar a otros ya que necesitará una empleada, también quiere ayudar a sus hijos para que sean unos profesionales que puedan valerse por sí solos en un futuro.
texts.en:
Mercedes is 35 years old. She studied until 5th grade. She is married and her partner works in a store. She has two children, one who is in 7th grade and one who is in 6th grade. Her two children and her partner live with her. 

Mercedes makes a living by selling food in a cafe at an institute. She has worked there for two years. She decided to open this business by herself. At first, she only sold water and cookies, but later began stocking the business with more and more things. Before starting the business, she performed household tasks and depended on her husband's income. Her workplace is located 15 minutes from her home and she travels on foot. She works from 7 a.m. until 4 p.m.

She needs the loan to purchase agricultural supplies to fertilize her husband's corn and bean plants. She will purchase sulfates and herbicides to control pests.

Mercedes dreams of stocking her business with more items so that she can earn more money and help other people since she needs an employee. She would also like to help her children to become professionals who can be self-sufficient in the future.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies like sulfate and herbicides to fertilize and control pests on her husband's corn and bean crops.

loans.name: Sheillah

texts.en:
Sheillah, age 30, earns an income by running a poultry feed shop. She has been working hard to manage her retail shop business for the past four years. She lives with her husband and their four children in the town of Kasangati in the Kampala east region. Three of the children are currently attending school. 
  
To help expand her business, Sheillah has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.
